sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a circular loop
message_1: A circular loop of radius 0.1 m carries a current of 2 A. Calculate the magnetic field strength at a point 0.2 m away from the center of the loop on its axis.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field strength at a point on the axis of a circular loop, we can use the formula:

B = (μ₀ * I * R²) / (2 * (R² + x²)^(3/2))

where B is the magnetic field strength, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current, R is the radius of the loop, and x is the distance from the center of the loop along its axis.

Given the values:
R = 0.1 m
I = 2 A
x = 0.2 m

Let's plug these values into the formula:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A * (0.1 m)²) / (2 * ((0.1 m)² + (0.2 m)²)^(3/2))

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm * 0.01 m²) / (2 * (0.01 m² + 0.04 m²)^(3/2))

B = (8π × 10^(-9) Tm) / (2 * (0.05 m²)^(3/2))

B = (8π × 10^(-9) Tm) / (2 * 0.125 m³)

B = (8π × 10^(-9) Tm) / (0.25 m³)

B ≈ 1.006 × 10^(-7) T

The magnetic field strength at a point 0.2 m away from the center of the loop on its axis is approximately 1.006 × 10^(-7) T.
